required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to study impairment of white blood cell function in patients with type II diabetes.

detailed_description.textblock: Leucocytes from poorly controlled diabetes exhibit aberrant chemotaxis, increased susceptibility to bacterial infection, leukotriene production, lysosomal enzyme release, proinflammatory cytokine expression and production of reactive oxygen species. Aberrant glucose concentration in diabetics affects functions of peripheral blood system as well as the immune system leading to impaired host defense. Impaired wound healing is a serious complication associated with diabetes. We hypothesized that impairment in leukocyte function results in dysfunctional inflammatory response in diabetic wounds. The proposed studies focus on characterizing mechanisms that will improve our understanding of the dysfunctional inflammatory response resulting in non-healing chronic wounds in diabetics.

primary_outcome.measure: Ex vivo leukocyte function by measuring ROS production
primary_outcome.description: After blood draw monocytes are separated from whole blood and production of oxidants by these cells

secondary_outcome.measure: Ex vivo NADPH oxidase gene and protein expression
secondary_outcome.description: Gene and protein expressions are measured using Western blot and real time PCR.

arm_group.description: Healthy subjects that do not have diabetes
Subject that have Type II Diabetes with good glucose control with glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c <7 or 7%)
Subjects with Type II Diabetes with moderate glucose control (HbA1c between 7.1-9)
Subjects with Type II Diabetes with poor glucose control (HbA1c >9%)

study_pop.textblock: Subjects will be recruited from the population who visit the Ohio State University (OSU) Hospitals and Comprehensive Wound Center (CWC), OSU Wexner Medical Center diabetic clinics and Bariatric clinic.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adults ages 40-60 yrs old clinically diagnosed with Type II Diabetes
- Adults ages 40-60 yrs old without Diabetes
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unable to provide informed consent
- Pregnant Females
- Therapeutically Immuno-compromised

overall_official.affiliation: Ohio State University Dept of Surgery

facility.name: Ohio State University Comprehensive Wound Center

link.description: OSU Center for Regenerative Medicine and Cell Based Therapies

results_reference.citation: Shurtz-Swirski R, Sela S, Herskovits AT, Shasha SM, Shapiro G, Nasser L, Kristal B. Involvement of peripheral polymorphonuclear leukocytes in oxidative stress and inflammation in type 2 diabetic patients. Diabetes Care. 2001 Jan;24(1):104-10.

Molenaar DM, Palumbo PJ, Wilson WR, Ritts RE Jr. Leukocyte chemotaxis in diabetic patients and their nondiabetic first-degree relatives. Diabetes. 1976;25(2 SUPPL):880-3.
Hill HR, Sauls HS, Dettloff JL, Quie PG. Impaired leukotactic responsiveness in patients with juvenile diabetes mellitus. Clin Immunol Immunopathol. 1974 Apr;2(3):395-403.
